ygData.subject: Re: Item Value and Use of Deterioration
ygData.msgSnippet: I like this idea a lot.  I agree that armor should not disappear just become less effective.  People will say that this would give people an uneasy feeling
ygData.messageBody:
I like this idea a lot. I agree that armor should not disappear just
become less effective. People will say that this would give people an
uneasy feeling knowing that they have to give their armor to a smith to
have it repaired. Maybe we could do the repairs while on the person or
you would exchange a new shirt for the worn one and some plat. Then
the smith could rework the old one to make as good as new to sell/trade
to another with a worn one.

--- "Kevin J. Hatch" <kjhatch5@...> wrote:
> From: "Kevin J. Hatch"
> <kjhatch5@...>
>
> Ok, here is another possible idea, what do you all
> think:
>
> Armor/Weapon QUALITY.
>
> This is no different than the idea of rusty and
> tarnished weapons
> already in use, and could extend to the
> well-balanced. I'm not
> advocating true item deterioration. The item would
> not go away. It
> simply gets "used" till it's not as good. Also
> magical items do not
> necessarily EVER get worn, they magically stay
> pristine. Weaker magic
> items, like those enchanted with minor bonuses would
> wear, but not Lore
> Items for example.
>
> So this is how it would work. A Player gets an item
> and uses it. From
> use (and not from sitting in a bank box) the item
> takes wear and the
> quality adjustment is made to it. If player faction
> can be tracked for
> every little thing, so can this. It can be computed
> after fights in the
> same way if need be. Worn items work less
> effectively. Less
> absorbtion/less AC, slower duration/less damage.
>
> Items which are worn are taken to a smith to
> repair/sharpen. The amount
> of improvement IS DEPENDENT ON THE SKILL OF THE
> SMITH. Master smiths do
> a better job. Average smiths can only repair to a
> certain level. This
> is both more realistic and helps make master more
> relevant.
>
> Then there's NPCs. Ok, so let NPCs sell all the
> same armor PCs can, at
> realistic prices. NPCs are not all masters.
> Different smiths have
> different skills. PCs will always be able to attain
> a higher skill than
> any NPC in the game. Items sold from an NPC will
> immediately not be of
> as good a quality as one made by a PC master. If a
> player wants to buy
> from an NPC at a cheaper price for a cheaper item,
> fine. The NPC prices
> ought to be lowered a bit, granted, but then that
> also goes to show that
> PCs would then sell based on their skill. Why
> should a master of 150
> sell his items for the same as a new smith of 80
> practicing gorgets?
> The master has worked his up and should get a better
> quality product.
>
> At the same time, NPCs should buy from PCs with
> quality in mind.
> Perhaps an NPC gives a level or two price below the
> selling price of a
> pristine piece. As you get higher into master, you
> get more profit from
> the selling. Initially the only way for a PC to
> make profit would be
> from other PCs, but then as you get might higher
> selling to NPCs would
> generate a profit. Smithing is expensive, as really
> all trades should
> be (relatively speaking). Brewing had the problem
> recently where you
> could buy for nothing and sell for much more to NPCs
> as master, and make
> master in an hour with only 5pp. They've reduced
> the profit to nearly
> nothing now, and are introducing more brews for
> higher skill
> advancement. The same can apply to smithing.
> Verant does not want
> people to be able to make a living on a trade
> selling to NPCs. But if a
> player must spend 150pp+ and spend long hours to
> become a master that
> makes just a little profit, good. It'll not be
> worth the time or
> money. What it'll do it also stabilize the economy.
> PCs wanting to buy
> weapons and armor will have to buy from the NPCs, or
> by from a player at
> better than what the NPC will take for it. The only
> real "deals" for
> players needing items will come from charity.
> Better smiths will get a
> better price from the NPC, and so their items will
> cost more to other
> players.
>
> The same goes for other trades like cooking, pottery
> and brewing that
> tend to be only a sell to NPC market. They will
> make a profit, but not
> that much and only more profit if they truly
> practice it higher. All
> skills should take a long time and more money to
> master. That will make
> the NPC profits more acceptable for Verant, and make
> being a master more
> valuable as less attain it. Think of tailoring
> where a master tailor
> making reinforced can make better armor than a below
> average smith just
> starting out. And the reinforced will be far
> lighter. It will make it
> more worthwhile to have ALL the armor types in use.
> All I see these
> days is banded and bronze plate. I don't even hear
> people selling ring
> anymore. Let smiths make it too. That's why I keep
> mentioning weapons,
> as smiths should be allowed to make them as much as
> any armor. (Hmm
> weapon smithing as a new skill separate from armor
> smithing...? bowyer
> and fletcher separate? tanner for hides, and tailor
> for sewing? People
> get to go to a "specialist" for their goods, again
> more realistic.)
>
> Items need not disappear. Battered armor doesn't
> just go away, it's all
> rusty and dented and needs some work. A smith can
> add some metal bits,
> and take his hammer and pliers to it and fix things
> up. At the same
> time, truly, all this magical item dropping from
> creatures should be
> scaled back a little. Regular weapons and armor
> dropped from mobs
> should be of "used" lesser quality. "Why buy from a
> smith when I can
> camp all I need from this mob?" Well because you
> get a better quality
> item for your money and the smith's time. It'll cut
> down on the campers
> for one, and then make it so that having a magical
> item is worth
> something. A quest that always returns an item will
> be more worthwhile
> than going after a mob that drops only 10% of the
> time. All regular
> armor would be purchased from smiths (NPC or PC) or
> at least repaired by
> a smith when found or bought in the field. PErhaps
> the thing to also do
> it make it so that lesser mobs for players in the
> teens and twenties
> tend to drop more "charged" items while the higher
> 30+ mobs drop more
> permanent effect items. Give out potions and 5 use
> items. When they
> are used up, they are useless or nearly so. That'll
> maintain this
> market of regular armors and weapons nicely. Just
> seem that regular
> items, leathers, chain, normal weapons are rare to
> all but those under
> level 5. Sad. There are constant auctions of all
> these "extra" magical
> items in every zone. It's as Monty Hall as it can
> get. Make it so
> Smiths can actually MAKE things, and then make it so
> what they make is
> USEFUL and then we will have a better place for
> smiths and well everyone
> else too.
>
> Dalinor
